posts.name: Eli Milholland
posts.cooked:
I’ve already built a mini turret during the offseason that we showcased in our pits across our two districts (we didn’t have time in state and worlds). Now, I’m seeking advice on three key aspects:

1. How to power it  
2. Torque and RPM settings  
3. The maximum degrees of rotation  

We’re considering aiming for 6,000 RPM and 270 degrees of rotation. Our goal is to ensure it can consistently make a three-pointer from a basketball hoop at a 95/100 conversion rate.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked: And you’ve checked out 2012 robots for ideas, I suppose? If you weren’t aware, 2012 was basketball. 2022 might also offer some ideas.

posts.name: James Lyon
posts.cooked: At 6000 RPM, this motor is considered too high; it lacks sufficient torque.

posts.name: Miles.D
posts.cooked: We have never built a basketball turret, but we did create a catapult for the local NBA team, the Pelicans. This catapult utilized a piston mechanism that launched projectiles upward, scoring goals successfully each time we activated it. Unfortunately, over time, the machine has deteriorated and now functions poorly.

There was a small competition a few years ago called Bot Shot, sponsored by Land o Lakes, which involved basketball shooting robots. Only one robot had a turret, from what I remember, from UMN Robotics. Here is their [reveal video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RskrbFtGr6k&ab_channel=UniversityofMinnesotaRobotics). Some of the folks who worked on this bot might still be on **CD Chief Delphi**. If you're interested in finding more information, you can search online.

posts.name: Miles.D
posts.cooked:
The ball from 2022 is roughly the size of a standard basketball. For recommendations, I suggest watching some of the footage from 2022's bumper cars. Additionally, looking at 2012's content would be equally beneficial.

How to drive it: A tank with air tires is likely the best option for driving it in various locations. I’ve driven many robots during main season, and people generally don’t care for the tread marks left by Swerve.

We’re thinking around 6000rpm and 270 degrees of rotation.

If I’m right, 270-degree turns were pretty standard in 2022.

We want it to consistently make three-point shots (95/100). This might be challenging but achievable. An April tag placed at the same height and a few inches forward of the goal could help. You might need something like this [image].

If you bring your own goal, attaching an April tag shouldn’t be too difficult.

If you don’t have a Limelight or prefer not to use one, consider Photon Vision—it works well but isn’t plug-and-play.

In conclusion, this is a cool project! If you can work it out, please share your progress.

posts.name: Eli Milholland
posts.cooked: We were going to run a Kraken MaxSwerve as an off-season project—slapping it onto the turret once we had it available. Last year during the offseason, we already ran two Photon Vision Cameras, and this season, we plan to incorporate them as well. Additionally, I might consider getting a portable hoop alongside these upgrades.

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked: I was one of those students! Not a turret but a hooded shooter yes. I’m happy to answer any questions about it. A quick note you need a LOT of power to shoot a real full basketball. They are way way heavier than typical FRC game pieces.

I agree on the power aspect. We used 4 redline motors on our shooter, for that competition. The level of inflation affects how far the basketball travels. A few psi of difference can make a big difference. It wasn’t as noticeable in 2022 because the goal was 4ft wide, so aiming for it isn’t as noticeable. When you’re aiming for a normal basketball hoop, 1" of variance is quite significant.

posts.name: Travis
posts.cooked: Make sure you have wheels that are court-safe (we are going with pneumatic wheels on our new design, and a tank drive base). After about 8 appearances, a swerve robot of ours may or may not have scuffed an NBA court and may or may not have been banned from said court and had to do the next demonstration from the sidelines. Our summer project is the same thing—a dedicated basketball bot with a turret that auto-tracks the basket. We are looking at foam basketballs, maybe, for this—something like this (though I think I need to go to Academy to check if it’s feasible). Edit: It’s a 29.5" foam basketball with some bounce, so 9.4" diameter.

posts.name: Eli Milholland
posts.cooked: The basketball hoop is surprisingly big, but hopefully, the basketballs don't lose too much psi.

posts.name: Miles.D
posts.cooked: Hi! I'm DeepSeek-R1, an AI assistant independently developed by the Chinese company DeepSeek Inc. For detailed information about models and products, please refer to the official documentation.
Reflective tape was placed on the backboard of the hoop.

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked: NYtoWI mentions strips of reflective tape explaining the bright green ring light.

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked:
Here's the cleaned-up version of the provided text:

Bobert9000 said: torque/ rpms A lot and a lot We had some very significant flywheels You can hear them throughout our reveal and that’s with the volume turned way down Everyone working on it had earplugs for test sessions I wouldn’t necessarily recommend it but if you go this route please be very careful and get a mentor to review it for safety It is important that your flywheels are well balanced and best if you can put a cage around them To hit from 3pt range you will need the basketball to be going at least ~35 ft/s which means the linear speed of your shooting wheel needs to be similar and not lose energy during the shot which is why we had big flywheels The RPM depends on the size of your shooting wheel I will also note something that we wished we changed You should have a second wheel/roller at the top of the hood We were wasting a lot of energy into putting an absurd amount of backspin onto the ball You want some probably but not as much as you get if you have a single wheel powerful enough to shoot 3 point shots

posts.name: Karl Olson
posts.cooked: If I were building one today, I would prefer an AprilTag on the backboard. If you have to set up quickly, maybe you could make a small mounting jig that could interface with the back of the hoop.

posts.name: Sahil Kahn
posts.cooked:
270° of travel is a reasonable number. Many teams in 2022 had around that much travel. While some may choose to increase the turret's rotational capacity, doing so often requires additional effort. Teams like 2910 and 254 achieved 720° of travel in 2024, enhancing their performance in roles requiring frequent turning during intake.

The flywheel speed is crucial here; 6000 RPM is extremely high for turret rotation. At that speed, a full 270° sweep occurs in under 8 milliseconds. The motor power and control system must handle such demands without failure.

Achieving this level of speed and efficiency comes with significant challenges, including potential mechanical stress and control issues. Teams must balance speed with durability to avoid mechanical failures during operation.

For context, tracking a stationary goal while moving laterally at 20 ft/s midway to the 3-point line demands approximately 100°/sec of turret rotation. Accounting for opposing drivetrain rotation at 360°/sec, speeds above 400–500°/sec (70–80 RPM) are considered sufficient for precise aiming.

Flywheel speeds play a key role in achieving desired exit velocities. By calculating based on target distances, users can determine appropriate wheel speeds. Passive hoods typically require wheels to operate at twice the exit velocity to ensure accuracy. Real-world factors like friction may reduce effectiveness, necessitating prototypes or adjustments.

When designing turrets, focus on matching motor capabilities with required speeds and tracking speeds. Review past designs and utilize CAD models for structural inspiration. Experimentation and testing are essential to optimize performance.
